description:
Amblyomma maculatum, commonly known as the Gulf Coast tick or Lone Star tick, is a species of hard tick that is native to the southeastern United States, as well as parts of Central and South America. It is a member of the Amblyomma genus, which includes several species of ticks that can transmit various diseases to humans and animals.

Amblyomma maculatum is a medium-sized tick, with adults typically measuring around 5-7 millimeters in length. The adult ticks have a distinctive pattern of white or yellowish spots on their dorsal (upper) surface, which gives them their common name of "Lone Star" ticks. The larvae and nymphs of this species do not have this distinctive marking.

These ticks are primarily found in grassy, wooded, or brushy habitats, and they feed on a variety of host animals, including deer, livestock, and humans. They can transmit several pathogens, including the bacteria that cause Rocky Mountain spotted fever, tularemia, and ehrlichiosis, as well as the protozoan parasite that causes babesiosis.

Amblyomma maculatum is considered an important public health concern in the regions where it is found, and it is the subject of ongoing research and monitoring efforts to better understand its ecology, distribution, and potential for disease transmission.
